*Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28*.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **Jennifer Collins**, pursuant to *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28*, *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20*, and the inherent equitable powers of this Honorable Court, and respectfully requests a **modification of the existing custody order** entered on **September 15, 2021**, in the **Worcester Probate and Family Court**, on the grounds that **a material and substantial change in circumstances** has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, such that modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the minor child, Ethan Collins (age 8)**.

*Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 20*.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, **Jennifer Collins**, pursuant to *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28*, *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20*, and the inherent equitable powers of this Honorable Court, and respectfully requests a **modification of the existing custody order** entered on **September 15, 2021**, in the **Worcester Probate and Family Court**, on the grounds that **a material and substantial change in circumstances** has occurred since the entry of the prior judgment, such that modification is necessary to serve the **best interests of the minor child, Ethan Collins (age 8)**.

*G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6*.proposition: The Court retains broad equitable power under *G.L. c. 215, § 6* and *Coppinger v. Coppinger*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 709 (2003),* to fashion custodial conditions, including supervised visitation, to ensure the child’s safety.*

*Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 31*.proposition: Pursuant to *Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 31*, shared custody requires parents to demonstrate the ability to communicate and cooperate; if such cooperation materially deteriorates, modification is appropriate.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that the “paramount consideration” in custody modification cases is the welfare and best interests of the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal/custody matters “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern” and interprets the governing statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests. Although this is a removal dispute within a divorce/custody context rather than a later modification proceeding, Massachusetts courts routinely treat such best‑interests language as generally applicable to custody determinations. Thus, the case supports the general proposition that the welfare and best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in custody-related decisions.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the “real advantage” test is grounded on the “realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.” Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, “[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.” Id. at 54.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.proposition: A material change in circumstances is one that affects the child’s welfare such that modification is necessary.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal / best-interests case and does not frame its analysis in terms of a ‘material change in circumstances’ standard or define that phrase. The only similar language appears in a quoted ALI provision stating that relocation may be a ‘substantial change in circumstances’ when it significantly impairs a parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities, but this is not adopted as Massachusetts’ definition and does not describe change in terms of affecting the child’s welfare such that modification is necessary. Thus the case does not support the specific proposition about what constitutes a material change in circumstances.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 184 (.relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:

“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]….”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A material change in circumstances is one that affects the child’s welfare such that modification is necessary.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies the statutory standard that modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28 requires a “material and substantial change in circumstances” and elaborates that this must be a change “of sufficient magnitude” such that transfer of custody will be conducive to the child’s welfare. While the case does not use the exact phrasing that modification must be “necessary,” its discussion of uprooting a child only for compelling reasons and tying the change in circumstances to the child’s welfare is substantively consistent with the proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’ Tolos v. Tolos, 11 Mass. App. Ct. 708, 710-711 (1981) (citation omitted).”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Allegations of parental substance abuse constitute a significant change warranting modification where such conduct endangers the minor child.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns relocation, paternity establishment, and the statutory rights of an unmarried mother as sole legal parent before paternity is adjudicated. It does not discuss parental substance abuse, endangerment from such abuse, or standards for modification based on changed circumstances. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that allegations of parental substance abuse constitute a significant change warranting modification.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. See ante at 550. As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is “free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].” Id. at 549-550. As a matter of law, it should make no difference to a parent’s freedom to relocate that another party subsequently files to establish parental rights.

*Adoption of Frederick*, 405 Mass. 1 (19.proposition: Allegations of parental substance abuse constitute a significant change warranting modification where such conduct endangers the minor child.
*Adoption of Frederick*, 405 Mass. 1 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns termination of parental rights and adoption, focusing on parental unfitness, the child’s emotional/developmental issues, and procedural questions about issue preclusion. It does not discuss allegations of parental substance abuse, nor does it address modification standards or changes in circumstances in that context. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that parental substance abuse constitutes a significant change warranting modification when it endangers the child.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..proposition: The Court must weigh evidence of instability or neglect in determining whether existing custodial arrangements continue to serve the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the best-interests standard and expressly states that the judge must weigh all relevant factors, including the child’s present and past living conditions and their impact on the child’s health. In affirming the custody award, the court relies heavily on evidence of the instability of Rose’s housing, daycare arrangements, work schedule, relocations, and her neglect of Jill’s emotional needs and relationship with Hunter. Thus, the case supports the proposition that courts must weigh instability or neglect when assessing whether existing or proposed custody arrangements serve the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

*Coppinger v. Coppinger*, 57 Mass. App..proposition: The Court retains broad equitable power under *G.L. c. 215, § 6* and *Coppinger v. Coppinger*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 709 (2003),* to fashion custodial conditions, including supervised visitation, to ensure the child’s safety.*
*Coppinger v. Coppinger*, 57 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion in Coppinger v. Coppinger deals exclusively with alimony modification standards and attorney’s fees in a contempt proceeding; it does not address child custody, visitation, supervised visitation, or the scope of the court’s equitable power under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to impose custodial conditions. Nothing in the reasoning or holding concerns ensuring a child’s safety through custodial conditions. Thus, citing Coppinger for broad equitable power to fashion custodial or visitation conditions is inaccurate and unsupported by this case.
*Coppinger v. Coppinger*, 57 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 215, § 34A, creates a presumption in favor of an award of reasonable fees and costs for a successful plaintiff in a contempt action. … This presumption ‘can be overcome only by specific findings supporting a reduction in a request for reasonable fees.’ … As the judge made no findings explaining the basis for the reduced award, we remand for reconsideration of the issue and entry of the required findings.

*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238 (199.proposition: *Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238 (1997),* emphasizes the Court’s responsibility to intervene when the custodial environment poses risk to a child’s physical or moral development.
*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly affirms that courts may and should limit parental rights, including religious liberty, when necessary to protect a child from physical or emotional harm and to safeguard the child’s best interests. The court upholds restrictions on the father’s religious activities with the children based on demonstrated and projected harm to their emotional and moral development, emphasizing that courts need not wait for severe psychiatric breakdown before intervening. This aligns with the proposition that the court has a responsibility to intervene when the custodial environment poses risks to a child’s physical or moral development.
*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238 (199.relevant_excerpt: “The case law does not require the court to wait for formal psychiatric breakdown and the evidence paints a strong picture of the reasonably projected course if the children continue to be caught in the cross-fire of their parents’ religious difference… At minimum they will be called upon to ‘choose’ between their parents, in itself a detrimental result.… Promoting the best interests of the children is an interest sufficiently compelling to impose a burden on the defendant’s right to practice religion… [T]his… is a constitutional limitation… as it is necessary to ensure the best interests of the children.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003),.proposition: *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003),* directs that existing orders must yield to new arrangements when material circumstances make continued enforcement contrary to a child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003),.support_reasoning: The case does not direct that existing orders must yield to new arrangements upon a material change in circumstances. Instead, it expressly declines to apply the modification/‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard of G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and treats the matter as an initial custody determination under the ‘best interests of the child’ standard in § 10(a). The discussion about preserving the status quo and avoiding disruption concerns how judges should approach temporary and initial custody orders, not when or how existing orders must give way to new arrangements because of changed circumstances.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003),.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..proposition: *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007),* and *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),* reiterate that a child’s safety and stability outweigh any parental preference.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The decision focuses on the constitutional and statutory rule that a fit parent is entitled to custody and that the State (or third parties) may not override that right merely because another placement would better serve the child’s best interests. While the court acknowledges the importance of the child’s welfare and the harm of disrupting an existing placement, it makes clear that a child cannot be transferred from a fit parent to others simply because the alternative home is safer, more stable, or otherwise preferable. Thus, the case does not stand for the broad proposition that a child’s safety and stability outweigh any parental preference; rather, it constrains that idea with the parental fitness requirement.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “But subsequent cases have established that this is not literally correct, for we do not transfer a child from his or her parent to other custodians merely because the latter may provide a more advantageous environment for the child’s upbringing. See Custody of a Minor, supra at 765 (‘Custody is not to be transferred from the [biological] parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the [biological] parent[] is inappropriate’).”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007),* and *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998),* reiterate that a child’s safety and stability outweigh any parental preference.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion does not state or imply a rule that a child’s safety and stability categorically outweigh any parental preference. Instead, it emphasizes that once parents are found unfit, the judge must select between competing placement plans based on the child’s best interests, giving no artificial or presumptive weight either to the department’s plan or to a plan proposed by the parents. The court explicitly rejects presumptions in favor of particular factors (such as bonding or sibling relationships) and insists on a flexible, case‑specific best‑interests analysis rather than a hierarchy where stability automatically trumps parental preferences.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Judges also ‘consider parental nominations of caretakers in an extended family, just as they do in other types of child custody cases.’ … We agree with the Appeals Court that a plan proposed by a parent is not ‘entitled to any artificial weight in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Nor is a plan proposed by DSS entitled to any special weight… Presented with more than one potential adoption placement, the judge’s task is to determine which plan will serve the best interests of the child, not to afford any particular weight to either plan.”
